Cells were grown in NZYM medium (1% N-Z-Case Plus (Sigma), 0.5% select yeast extract (Sigma), 0.5% NaCl, and 0.2% MgSO4) containing the appropriate antibiotics (ampicillin at 100 μg/ml, kanamycin at 20 μg/ml) at 37 °C, 250 rpm until A600 0.6–0.8. Induction of expression and purification of isolated domain III of Calpain B was carried out according to Tompa et al. (16Tompa P. Emori Y. Sorimachi H. Suzuki K. Friedrich P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2001; 280: 1333-1339Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar) with the exception that Talon-affinity chromatography was applied prior to renaturation. Renaturation was carried out by removal of urea by stepwise dialysis in buffer A (50 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl) containing 1 m NaCl and 8–4-2–1-0.5–0 m urea, at least for 8 h in each case. The renatured protein was dialyzed into buffer A and used immediately for equilibrium dialysis. Calpain B was prepared from both the soluble and the insoluble fractions of E. coli. To obtain wild type or mutant Calpain B from the bacterial cytosol, expression of the protein was induced by 0.05 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside at 20 °C for 3 h. The culture was cooled on ice and centrifuged at 3000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C. Cells were suspended in lysis buffer (50 mm NaH2PO4/Na2HPO4, pH 7.5, 300 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 5 mm benzamidine, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 mm β-mercaptoethanol) and sonicated for 6 × 15 s at 16 μm on ice. The lysate was centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 60 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was applied to a 5-ml Ni-NTA resin equilibrated with Ni-NTA buffer (lysis buffer with the exception of EDTA is 0.2 mm). The column was washed with Ni-NTA buffer containing 2% glycerol, 1% Tween 20, and 10 mm imidazole. Calpain B was eluted with a linear gradient of imidazole from 20 to 250 mm in Ni-NTA buffer. Calpain B was dialyzed into and stored in buffer A containing 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm benzamidine, 0.25 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 10 mm β-mercaptoethanol at 4 °C. Calpain B was also prepared from inclusion bodies according to Jekely and Friedrich (23Jekely G. Friedrich P. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 23893-23900Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). In this case, expression was induced with 0.5 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside at 30 °C for 3 h. The enzyme otherwise behaved the same as the cytosolic preparation. Expression of wild type or mutant rat m-calpain was induced with 0.4 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside at 30 °C for 3 h. The culture was cooled on ice and centrifuged at 3000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C. Cells were suspended in lysis buffer and sonicated for 6 × 15 s at 16 μm on ice. The lysate was centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 60 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was applied to a 5 ml of Ni-NTA resin equilibrated with Ni-NTA buffer. The column was washed with Ni-NTA buffer containing 20 mm imidazole, and elution was carried out with Ni-NTA buffer containing 250 mm imidazole. All of the enzyme preparations were sufficiently pure for kinetic analysis as detected by SDS-PAGE (Fig. 3) Equilibrium Dialysis—Equilibrium dialysis could be carried out with Calpain B domain III but not with m-calpain domain III because of the instability of the latter. The protein (1–1.5 mg/ml) in 50 μl of buffer A was put into the dialysis tubes. The bags were then transferred into vials containing 500 μl of buffer A with 5 mm β-mercaptoethanol and appropriate concentrations of 45Ca2+. After 18–20 h dialysis at 4 °C, aliquots (10 μl) were taken from the equilibrating buffer and from the sample within the bag and counted for radioactivity in a liquid scintillation counter (Wallac 1409 DSA). Conditions were set so that the radioactivity of samples was within 20,000–30,000 cpm in 2 ml of scintillation mixture. The amount of 45Ca2+ bound to the protein was calculated from the differences between the radioactivity present in the bags and in the outside buffer. When carrying out dialysis in the presence of liposomes, the concentration of liposomes was 0.1 mg/ml both inside and outside the bag. Bovine serum albumin at a concentration (mg/ml) equal to domain III was used as a control to calculate nonspecific interactions. SDS-PAGE and densitometry were applied to determine the exact concentration of protein inside the bags at the end of dialysis. Preparation of Liposomes—Liposomes were prepared from a crude bovine brain extract of phosphoinositides (Sigma P6023) according to Tompa et al. (16Tompa P. Emori Y. Sorimachi H. Suzuki K. Friedrich P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2001; 280: 1333-1339Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar). Ca2+ Overlay Assay—Samples containing 1 μg of protein in 8 m urea/buffer A were spotted on a 1 × 5-cm strip of nitrocellulose membrane pre-wetted with distilled water. The membrane was washed for 2 × 10 min with buffer A, placed on a sheet of Parafilm, and incubated with 400 μl of 30 μm 45Ca2+ (400 MBq/mmol) on a rocking shaker for 20 min at room temperature. After incubation, the membrane was washed briefly with water and dried for autoradiography on AGFA CP-B medical x-ray film. Dot intensities were determined by densitometry in a Bio-Rad GelDoc 1000 video densitometer. Fluorometric Assay of Calpain Activity—Calpain activity was measured in a JASCO FP 777 spectrofluorometer, continuously recording the increase of fluorescence corresponding to the cleavage of the substrate N-succinyl-Leu-Tyr-7-amino-4-methyl-coumarin (Sigma). The excitation wavelength was 380 nm, and emission was monitored at 460 nm. Reactions were set up in a final volume of 50 μl in buffer A containing 1 mm EDTA at room temperature. The concentration of the fluorescent substrate was 1 mm. Free Ca2+ concentration was adjusted to the value indicated. The reaction was started by the addition of calpain. The free Ca2+ concentration was determined by a commercial Ca2+-selective electrode. With Calpain B and, to a lesser extent, with m-calpain, there is a lag phase in the progress curve corresponding to activation (23Jekely G. Friedrich P. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 23893-23900Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar) during which enzyme activity increases until it reaches a maximum, later to decline because of slow inactivation. The maximal slope of the progress curves, determined as the maximum of the derivative relative to time, yielded enzyme activity. Specific Activity—The specific activity was calculated as the ratio of maximal activity at 5 mm free Ca2+ concentration, and the enzyme concentration was determined by the Bradford method (21Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (211906) Google Scholar). The protein content of the enzyme preparations was taken to represent the active enzymes on the following basis. Only freshly prepared enzymes were used, and the specific activities were determined on the next day after preparation. After overnight dialysis into buffer A containing 1 mm EDTA, the preparations were centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C to remove any denatured and aggregated proteins. The preparations were homogenous on SDS-PAGE (Fig. 3). Determination of the Number of Catalytic Cycles—At different concentrations (0.01–1 mm) of N-succinyl-Leu-Tyr-7-amino-4-methyl-coumarin, substrate hydrolysis was monitored for 1–3 h with repeated additions of m-calpain to determine the total change in fluorescence intensity caused by the full consumption of substrate. From these measurements, we obtained that deltaF (in arbitrary units) equals 250 for 1 μm substrate cleaved. This calibration was used to calculate the number of catalytic cycles performed by a given concentration of the enzyme (see below for mutant M-Δ395–404). Ca2+ Binding to Domain III of Drosophila Calpain B—The number and affinity of the Ca2+-binding sites of wild-type domain III were determined by equilibrium dialysis (Fig. 4). Domain III can bind three Ca2+ ions with a Kd of 3400 μm in the absence of liposomes and two Ca2+ ions with a Kd of 220 μm in the presence of liposomes. Thus, liposomes produce a significant increase in the affinity for Ca2+. The effect of mutations (for definition, see Fig. 2) of the acidic loop of domain III could not be studied by equilibrium dialysis because of the poor solubility of the mutants generated. Nevertheless, their Ca2+ binding could be assessed and compared with that of wild-type domain III by an overlay assay on dot blots (Table II) because the proteins thus examined were homogeneous by SDS-PAGE (data not shown). The mutant and wild-type domain III samples were denatured in 8 m urea and then were spotted on nitrocellulose membrane and then washed in buffer A (see “Experimental Procedures”). This washing step apparently brought the proteins to the native form, because the binding capacity of each mutant was different in a highly reproducible manner in ∼10 parallel experiments. In case of unspecific denaturation, we would not expect such a distinct and reproducible pattern. We found that wild-type domain III of Calpain B has the highest capacity for binding Ca2+, whereas the BIII-E610A/D611A/P612A,Δ613–620 deletion mutant, which lacks all of the acidic amino acids of the loop, is practically unable to bind Ca2+. The BIII-P612A,Δ613–620 deletion mutant, in which the whole loop is excised but two acidic groups next to the loop are present, retains approximately one-third of the original Ca2+-binding capacity. Mutations in the N-terminal part of the loop have greater effect on Ca2+ binding than mutations in the C-terminal part. For example, the BIII-D617N/D618N mutant binds twice as much Ca2+ as the BIII-D613N/D614N mutant, 60 and 30% binding capacity of wild type. The BIII-E610Q/D611N/D613N/D614N mutant (four amino acids changed in the N-part of the loop) has 16.2% binding capacity, whereas BIII-E615Q/D616N/D617N/D618N (four mutations in the C-part of the loop) binds 36%. In general, the more acidic amino acids are substituted with neutral ones, the lower the capacity is to bind Ca2+. Overall, from the Ca2+ overlay assay, we can draw the conclusion that the acidic loop of Calpain B domain III and its two adjoining residues on the N-terminal side are responsible for Ca2+ binding of the domain.Table IICa2+ binding to wild type and mutant recombinant domains III of Calpain B 1 μg of wild type or mutant domain III was dotted on a nitrocellulose membrane and laid over with 45Ca2+. Radioactivity of Ca2+ bound to the protein was visualized by autoradiography. The effect of phospholipids, which increase the strength of Ca2+ binding by approximately an order of magnitude and lower the number of bound ions possibly due to steric hindrance, is in line with prior da

The quality of nascent protein folding in vivo is influenced by the microdynamics of the proteins. Excessive collisions between proteins may lead to terminal misfolding, and the frequency of protein interactions with molecular chaperones determines their folding rates. However, it is unclear how immature protein dynamics are regulated. In this study, we analyzed the diffusion of immature tyrosinase in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of non-pigmented cells by taking advantage of the thermal sensitivity of the tyrosinase. The diffusion of tyrosinase tagged with yellow fluorescence protein (YFP) in living cells was directly measured using fluorescent correlation spectroscopy. The diffusion of folded tyrosinase in the ER of cells treated with brefeldin A, as measured by fluorescent correlation spectroscopy, was critically affected by the expression level of tyrosinase-YFP. Under defined conditions in which random diffusional motion of folded protein was allowed, we found that the millisecond-order diffusion rate observed for folded tyrosinase almost disappeared for the misfolded molecules synthesized at a nonpermissive high temperature. This was not because of enhanced aggregation at the high temperature, as terminally misfolded tyrosinase synthesized in the absence of calnexin interactions showed comparable, albeit slightly slower, diffusion. Yet, the thermally misfolded tyrosinase was not immobilized when measured by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching. In contrast, terminally misfolded tyrosinase synthesized in cells in which α-glucosidases were inhibited showed extensive immobilization. Hence, we suggest that the ER represses random fluctuations of immature tyrosinase molecules while preventing their immobilization. The maturation of proteins in the secretory pathway requires various sequential reactions including suppression of backward movements through the translocational channel by BiP (1Matlack K.E. Misselwitz B. Plath K. Rapoport T.A. Cell. 1999; 97: 553-564Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (307) Google Scholar); cleavage of the signal sequence and attachment of N-linked oligosaccharides (2Kornfeld R. Kornfeld S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1985; 54: 631-664Crossref PubMed Scopus (3762) Google Scholar); the prevention of nonproductive folding intermediates by various molecular chaperones (3Stevens F.J. Argon Y. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 1999; 10: 443-454Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar); disulfide shuffling by disulfide isomerases possessing chaperone activity (4Ferrari D.M. Soling H.D. Biochem. J. 1999; 339: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (440) Google Scholar, 5Freedman R.B. Klappa P. Ruddock L.W. EMBO Rep. 2002; 3: 136-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar); and proline isomerization (6Bose S. Freedman R.B. Biochem. J. 1994; 300: 865-870Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). When these processes are not completed, proteins are disposed eventually. Recent extensive studies have been revealing the underlying molecular mechanisms of this destruction (7Fewell S.W. Travers K.J. Weissman J.S. Brodsky J.L. Annu. Rev. Genet. 2001; 35: 149-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar, 8Benham A.M. Braakman I. Crit. Rev. Biochem. Mol. Traffic. 2002; 3: 530-536Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 11Braakman I. EMBO Rep. 2001; 2: 666-668Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). However, there are also misfolded proteins that are able to maintain reversible folding for several hours after synthesis but somehow fail to exit the ER. 1The abbreviations used are: ER, endoplasmic reticulum; CFP, cyan fluorescent protein; FCS, fluorescence correlation spectroscopy; FRAP, fluorescence recovery after photobleaching; YFP, yellow fluorescent protein; DOPA, dihydroxyphenylalanine; VSVG, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein. 1The abbreviations used are: ER, endoplasmic reticulum; CFP, cyan fluorescent protein; FCS, fluorescence correlation spectroscopy; FRAP, fluorescence recovery after photobleaching; YFP, yellow fluorescent protein; DOPA, dihydroxyphenylalanine; VSVG, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein.A temperature-sensitive ts045 variant of the vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSVG) is the best known example (12Gallione C.J. Rose J.K. J. Virol. 1985; 54: 374-382Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 13Doms R.W. Keller D.S. Helenius A. Balch W.E. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 1957-1969Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar, 14Hammond C. Helenius A. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 41-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). It was thought that the defect in the exit of this glycoprotein from the ER and its transport to the Golgi could be explained by (a) uncompleted interactions of cargo proteins with the “ER matrix,” which is composed of various chaperones and folding enzymes (15Tatu U. Helenius A. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 555-565Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar, 16Meunier L. Usherwood Y.K. Chung K.T. Hendershot L.M. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 4456-4469Crossref PubMed Scopus (425) Google Scholar) or (b) misfolded aggregates (13Doms R.W. Keller D.S. Helenius A. Balch W.E. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 1957-1969Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) that are too large to enter the COPII-coated ER exit sites. However, measurements of the misfolded VSVG mutant in living cells using fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) (17Axelrod D. Koppel D.E. Schlessinger J. Elson E. Webb W.W. Biophys. J. 1976; 16: 1055-1069Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2013) Google Scholar) surprisingly showed that the thermal-induced misfolding caused no significant loss of lateral mobility (18Nehls S. Snapp E.L. Cole N.B. Zaal K.J. Kenworthy A.K. Roberts T.H. Ellenberg J. Presley J.F. Siggia E. Lippincott-Schwartz J. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 288-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). While various models can be conceived to explain the results, the study at least eliminated the possibility that the misfolded VSVG failed to exit because it is tethered to the immobile ER matrix (19Hendershot L.M. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: E105-E106Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Movements of newly synthesized proteins could affect their folding per se. Collision of two molecules exposing hydrophobic patches on their surfaces could result in the formation of aggregates. Also, folding rates depend on the frequency of collision with molecular chaperones. Hence, it is expected that the mobility of proteins during folding is regulated in living cells. However, this is hard to measure by FRAP because FRAP records the average motion of a mass population and its time resolution is not sufficient for complicated dynamics including submillisecond diffusion. For measuring such random diffusional motion of an individual protein, fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS) is, at present, the only practical method (20Rigler R. Elson E.L. Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy: Theory and Applications. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2001Crossref Google Scholar, 21Elson E.L. Traffic. 2001; 2: 789-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar, 22Hess S.T. Huang S. Heikal A.A. Webb W.W. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 697-705Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar). FCS detects fluctuation of the fluorescence intensity in a confocally defined volume with a sharply focused laser. This method has been developed as a unique technique to measure translational and rotational diffusion coefficients of molecules in solution and in living cells (22Hess S.T. Huang S. Heikal A.A. Webb W.W. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 697-705Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar, 23Widengren J. Rigler R. Cell. Mol. Biol. (Noisy-le-grand). 1998; 44: 857-879PubMed Google Scholar, 24Foldes-Papp Z. Demel U. Tilz G.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 11509-11514Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 25Larson D.R. Ma Y.M. Vogt V.M. Webb W.W. J. Cell Biol. 2003; 162: 1233-1244Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Application of this technique to biological systems has brought to light novel aspects of various molecular dynamisms, such as the status of the tubulin complex in kinesin-mediated axonal transport in the squid giant axon (26Terada S. Kinjo M. Hirokawa N. Cell. 2000; 103: 141-155Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). However, this method has not been used to analyze the process of protein maturation in living cells. To study the dynamics of immature proteins, we reasoned that we might be able to use the thermal sensitivity of tyrosinase, a melanosomal membrane enzyme catalyzing the oxidation of monohydric phenols, a critical step in melanin biosynthesis (EC 1.14.18.1) (27Hearing V.J. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 142: 154-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (223) Google Scholar). Failure to express its catalytic activity results in the occurrence of oculocutaneous albinism type I (28Spritz R.A. Hearing V.J. Hirschhorn K. Harris H. Advances in Human Genetics. Plenum Press, New York1994: 1-5Crossref Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Pigment cells from individuals with some types of this disorder are temperature-sensitive (29Halaban R. Svedine S. Cheng E. Smicun Y. Aron R. Hebert D.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 5889-5894Crossref PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar, 30Toyofuku K. Wada I. Spritz R.A. Hearing V.J. Biochem. J. 2001; 355: 259-269Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). When wild type tyrosinase is expressed in non-pigmented cells, its folding is also sensitive to heat (31Berson J.F. Frank D.W. Calvo P.A. Bieler B.M. Marks M.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12281-12289Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). Expression Vectors and Culture Cells—The adenovirus vector used to express tyrosinase is described elsewhere (41Hirosaki K. Yamashita T. Wada I. Jin H.Y. Jimbow K. J. Investig. Dermatol. 2002; 119: 475-480Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). EcoRI and BamHI sites were attached to the human tyrosinase cDNA (35Toyofuku K. Wada I. Hirosaki K. Park J.S. Hori Y. Jimbow K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1999; 125: 82-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Tyrosinase fused to yellow fluorescent protein (YFP) or cyan fluorescent protein (CFP) was then produced by ligating the human tyrosinase into pEYFP-N1 or pECFP-N1 (BD Bioscience) cut with EcoRI and BamHI, respectively. For construction of the Sar1(T39N) expression vector, Sar1 cDNA was isolated by reverse transcription from HepG2 RNA using the primer 5′-GGATCAGTCCAGAGAAGTAAAAC-3′, then amplified by PCR with the pair of primers 5′-GCCGGAGAGCCCCTCAGGCCGTAGTAAGC-3′ and 5′-TCACCGTCCAAACATCAGTCAATATACTGG-3′. Restriction sites for BglII and KpnI were created at the 5′ and 3′ ends of the Sar1 cDNA using PCR. The Sar1 cDNA was then ligated into the corresponding sites of pEYFP-N1Δ whose EYFP open reading frame was removed by restriction with BamHI and NotI followed by ligation after polishing the terminus. To construct the GDP-restricted form of Sar1, the codon for Thr at amino acid 36 was mutated to that encoding Asn using the QuikChange™ protocol (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). An expression vector for CFP-GT-(1-81) (GT-(1-81); the amino-terminal 81 amino acids of human β-1,4-galactosyltransferase) were purchased from Clontech. A vector for VSVG (ts045) was described previously (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). These vectors were introduced directly into cells using siliconized glass microbeads (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). SiHa and COS7 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA). COS7 cells stably expressing hSec13-YFP were generated as follows. The coding sequence of human Sec13-YFP (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) was subcloned into the appropriate cloning sites of the retrovirus expression vector, pCX4bsr. pCX4bsr, a generous gift from Dr. T. Akagi (Osaka BioScience Institute), is a modified version of pCXbsr (43Akagi T. Shishido T. Murata K. Hanafusa H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 7290-7295Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar) that lacks the internal initiation codons within the gag region. The recombinant retrovirus was generated as described (43Akagi T. Shishido T. Murata K. Hanafusa H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 7290-7295Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar) and used to infect COS7 cells. The cells expressing hSec13 were selected by culturing them in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing blasticidin (10 μg/ml). Analysis of Protein Dynamics in Living Cells—Live cell analysis using the microscopy was essentially described previously (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The culture temperature of cells on the microscope stage was controlled using an objective heater for a planapochromat lens ×63 (Bioptechs, Butler, PA) or a Silicon Heater (Cell MicroControls, Norfolk, VA) for a C-Apochromat ×40 lens in combination with a stage heater (Kitazato Supply, Fujinomiya, Japan). To monitor the temperature of the cells under observation, an infrared thermometer (model CT820, CITIZEN Co., Tokyo, Japan) was used. For confocal microscopy and FCS analysis, a ConfoCor2 instrument (Zeiss, Jena, Germany) was used. Confocal images were taken with the laser scanning microscopy module. The excitation light of an argon ion laser at 514 nm was reflected by a dichroic mirror (HFT 514) and focused through a C-Apochromat ×40, NA = 1.2 water immersion objective (pinhole width 70 μm). A 530-560 nm band-pass filter was used to filter out the remaining scattered laser light. In all measurements, the minimum laser power of the setup was used. The fluorescence signal was recorded for three consecutive periods of 15 s (time resolution, 200 ns). The autocorrelation function and data fitting was performed with the software provided with the setup. Indirect immunofluorescence of fixed cells and time-lapse analysis of fluorescent molecules in live cells were carried out and processed as described previously by Nagaya et al. (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). For FRAP experiments, an area (1 μm2) was exposed to the maximum power of the argon laser and then the recovery from the bleaching was measured at the minimum power of the laser. The obtained data were analyzed by fitting to a formula for one-dimensional diffusion (44Spector D.L. Goldman R.D. Leinwand L.A. Cells: A Laboratory Manual. 2. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1997Google Scholar) using Prism version 3.0 software (San Diego, CA). Tyrosinase Activity Measurements and Sedimentation Analysis—Active staining of DOPA oxidase and spectrophotomeric measurements of DOPA oxidase activity in cellular lysates were carried out as described (35Toyofuku K. Wada I. Hirosaki K. Park J.S. Hori Y. Jimbow K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1999; 125: 82-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). To determine the sedimentation velocity of tyrosinase synthesized under various culture conditions, cells in a 60-mm dish were lysed with 0.5 ml of 1% sodium cholate, 0.15 m NaCl, 20 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.2, and directly loaded onto a sucrose gradient from 25 to 10% in 0.3% sodium cholate, 0.15 m NaCl, 20 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.2, in a tube for a Hitachi RPS40T rotor. After centrifugation at 36,000 rpm for 18 h at 4 °C, ten 1-ml fractions were collected from the bottom of the tube and 10 μl from each fraction was subjected to immunoblot analysis using an anti-tyrosinase monoclonal antibody (Novocastra Laboratories Ltd., Balliol Business Park West, UK). FCS Measurements of Tyrosinase Expressed in Non-pigmented Cells—To test whether we could use the reported thermal sensitivity of tyrosinase folding to synchronize its maturation, we first examined the heat lability of its folding and stability. A recombinant adenovirus was used to express tyrosinase in human cervical carcinoma SiHa cells for 24 h at 37 °C and at various other temperatures (Fig. 1A). For the cells incubated at 37 °C, protein synthesis was halted by the addition of puromycin and the cells were further incubated for 24 h at the indicated temperatures. The cells were then lysed with detergents and the DOPA oxidase activity was determined (35Toyofuku K. Wada I. Hirosaki K. Park J.S. Hori Y. Jimbow K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1999; 125: 82-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The DOPA oxidase activity was dramatically reduced when tyrosinase was synthesized above 39 °C (Fig. 1A, inset). In contrast, thermal treatment of folded tyrosinase (i.e. tyrosinase synthesized at 37 °C) had little effects on the activity, indicating that completion of tyrosinase folding is arrested above 39 °C. Importantly, when the inactive tyrosinase formed at 40 °C was further incubated at 37 °C in the presence of puromycin, the protein became almost fully active with 60 min (Fig. 1A, squares). This activation was not observed in ATP-depleted medium (circles) or in the presence of an α-glucosidase inhibitor (triangles). We then used this protocol to study how the mobility of tyrosinase is regulated during maturation. We reasoned that the diffusion profile of thermally misfolded tyrosinase may be distinct from the properly folded molecule if there is any regulation of mobility. To analyze mobility, we used FCS because this technique has the highest time resolution of the available techniques. However, it is known that FCS is often too sensitive to analyze cellular processes (21Elson E.L. Traffic. 2001; 2: 789-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). In particular, photobleaching is a major obstacle. We therefore examined the conditions in which FCS could detect random diffusion in living cells. Because the degree of photobleaching obtained by FCS should correlate with the density of the molecules, we investigated which expression level would largely allow for random diffusion. In cells where the expression level is too high, the molecules would be at least partially immobilized. To achieve various levels of expression, we used siliconized glass microbeads (42Nagaya H. Wada I. Jia Y.-J. Kanoh H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 302-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). When photon-counting of tyrosinase-YFP was carried out in formalin-fixed cells, all fluorophores showed rapid decay of fluorescence to near background within 45 s, as expected (Fig. 1B, left panel). The fluctuation of the signal was almost at the level of noise, and no autocorrelation was observed from this counting (not shown). We next examined whether this setup could detect diffusion of tyrosinase-YFP expressed in a living cell at 37 °C for 2 h in the presence of brefeldin A, which prevents export from the ER (45Misumi Y. Miki K. Takatsuki A. Tamura G. Ikehara Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 11398-11403Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this measurement, the degree of photobleaching was reduced compared with that in the fixed cells, and massive signal fluctuation was observed (Fig. 1B, right panel). When we plotted the extent of bleaching, B, against the expression level, Iini, we noticed that the relationship largely fits a simple saturable binding model: B = Bmax·Iini/(K + Iini). The constant K reflects the degree of correlation between photobleaching and the expression level. In the case of fixed cells, K should be ∼0. If the level of tyrosinase expression has little influence on diffusional motion in the membrane, K should far exceed Iini. This would happen if the fluorophore is very bright, so that the number of expressed molecules is very small. However, when measured in the living cells, this is not the case. In the living cells, a significant correlation was observed between the two values when the initial count rate was below 100 kHz (Fig. 1C, ×), suggesting that at least tyrosinase-YFP was not saturated at this range and, thus, random diffusion of tyrosinase-YFP should be measurable. Regulation of Diffusional Mobility of Thermally Misfolded Tyrosinase—We next expressed tyrosinase-YFP at 40 °C and plotted the degree of photobleaching against the number of misfolded molecules. Surprisingly, massive photobleaching was observed irrespective of the expression level (Fig. 2A). A typical decay curve is shown in Fig. 2B (top panel), which resembles that of the fixed protein (Fig. 1B). It should be noted that, different from the fixed cells, the decay in living cells reached a plateau at a significantly higher level than background (∼1 kHz), suggesting the presence of a slow movement of nonbleached tyrosinase into the bleached area. However, this mobility was too slow to be captured by FCS. Nonetheless, the counting showed almost no autocorrelation over time (Fig. 2C, black line). To know if this lack of fluctuation is reversed when folding is allowed, we recorded the fluorescence in the same spot over a temperature shift from 40 °C (Fig. 2B, top) to 37 °C (Fig. 2B, middle and bottom). In these cases, fluctuation emerged upon temperature shift (Fig. 2B, middle). Interestingly, an almost identical autocorrelation curve was observed when incubation was continued at 37 °C for another 10 min (Fig. 2C, red line), except for a slight increase in the population with the faster mobility in the millisecond range. A two-component fitting analysis indicated that the mobility was composed of fast (T = 0.64 ms, 50.7%) and slow (T = 9.17 ms, 49.3%) diffusion components (Fig. 2C, bottom panel). While these results indicated that the random diffusion detected by FCS was suppressed at 40 °C, they also suggested that the protein was slowly mobile at this temperature. We therefore examined whether such dynamics might be detected by FRAP. To test this possibility, we first assayed the rates of reversible photobleaching in fixed cells (46Swaminathan R. Hoang C.P. Verkman A.S. Biophys. J. 1997; 72: 1900-1907Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (482) Google Scholar). An area of a formalin-fixed tyrosinase-YFP was photobleached by a pulse of intense laser beam, and the recovery rate was determined. As shown in Fig. 3A, the maximum laser beam reduced the signal to 42% of the initial level and within 1 s the intensity increased to 50% and remained there, suggesting that any recovery above 50% should be because of fluorophore exchange between the bleached and unbleached areas. We then determined the fraction of immobilized molecules in the living cells. While the fluorescence intensity of an area of tyrosinase-YFP synthesized for 2 h at 40 °C was reduced almost as much as it was in the fixed cell by an intense laser beam, the signal in the area recovered almost fully (Fig. 3B, red). Similarly, full recovery from photobleaching was observed in the adjacent area when the cell was incubated on the stage at 37 °C for 15 min after 40 °C expression for 2 h although it appeared to be slightly faster (Fig. 3B, blue). These results and further independent experiments, as summarized in Fig. 3C, indicates that tyrosinase synthesized at 40 °C was slow, but fully mobile. Diffusional Mobility of Aggregated Tyrosinase Formed in Castanospermine-treated Cells—To know whether the apparent lack of random diffusion seen with FCS measurements at non-permissive temperatures was because of the formation of large aggregates, we measured the molecular weight of detergent-solubilized tyrosinase using sedimentation analysis through sucrose density gradients. As shown in Fig. 4A, tyrosinase synthesized at the non-permissive temperature, 40 °C, was mostly found in the bottom three fractions of the gradient (red line). After 30 min at 37 °C, the majority was still found in the bottom fractions, but a slight increase in the recovery in fractions 4 and 5 was observed (green line). After 1 h at 37 °C, a small decrease in the percentage of tyrosinase in the bottom fraction was detected (blue line). An almost identical pattern was obtained at 2 h postincubation. 2A. Kamada, H. Nagaya, T. Tamura, M. Kinjo, H.-Y. Jin, T. Yamashita, K. Jimbow, H. Kanoh, and I. Wada, unpublished data. However, the molecules did not acquire the compact tertiary structure detected for the native enzyme synthesized without exposure to 40 °C (black line). When we examined terminally misfolded tyrosinase synthesized in the presence of an α-glucosidase inhibitor, castanospermine, the majority of the molecules were recovered in the bottom fractions, suggesting that they are largely aggregated. This analysis suggests that a slight alteration in size of tyrosinase aggregates is associated with the acquisition of activity, and that the thermally misfolded tyrosinase is structurally distinct from terminally misfolded tyrosinase. To examine the possibility that the suppression of millisecond diffusion at the non-permissive temperature was caused by enhanced aggregation, we measured diffusion of the terminally misfolded tyrosinase synthesized in castanospermine-treated cells at 37 °C. However, in this case, the autocorrelation analysis showed that the diffusion of the slower mobility component was slightly slower but detectable by FCS (Fig. 5A). The typical measurement showed that the diffusion was composed of a fast (586.8 μs, 45.6%) and a slow (18.7 ms, 54.4%) diffusion (Fig. 5A). A summary of FCS measurements at various conditions is also shown in Fig. 5B. Hence, we conclude that the lack of autocorrelation at the non-permissive temperature was not the result of enlarged aggregates. However, FRAP analysis of the castanospermine-treated cells showed that the maximum recovery rate was reduced by ∼30% (Fig. 5C). Taken together, we reasoned that l

At the spoIIG promoter phosphorylated Spo0A (Spo0A∼P) binds 0A boxes overlapping the -35 element, interacting with RNA polymerase to facilitate open complex formation. We have compared in vitro transcription from a series of heteroduplex templates containing denatured regions within the promoters. Transcription from heteroduplex templates with 12, 8, or 6 base pairs denatured was independent of Spo0A∼P, but heteroduplexes with 4 or 2 base pairs denatured required Spo0A∼P for maximal levels of transcription. Investigation of the thermal dependence of transcription suggested that strand separation was the primary thermodynamic barrier to transcription initiation but indicated that Spo0A∼P does not reduce this energetic barrier. Kinetic assays revealed that Spo0A∼P stimulated both the rate of formation of initiated complexes as well as increasing the number of complexes capable of initiating transcription. These results imply that Spo0A∼P stimulates transcription at least in part by stabilizing the RNA polymerase-spoIIG complex until contacts between RNA polymerase and the -10 element induce strand separation.
